facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 383 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 383 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 10, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in Appeals Suit Nos. 577 and 751 of 1958 and 40 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal is from judgment and decree dated August 10, 1960 of Kerala High Court

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 10, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in Appeals Suit Nos. 577 and 751 of 1958 and 40 of 1959.

facts.text: Kerala High Court appeals are Suit Nos. 577 and 751 of 1958 and 40 of 1959

anchor.surface_text: the Kerala High Court in Appeals Suit Nos. 577 and 751 of 1958 and 40 of 1959. N. Subramania lyer, M. S. K. Sastri and M. S. Narasimhan, for the appellant.

facts.text: Kerala High Court single Judge dismissed appellant's suit for recovery of possession of certain property and mesne profits

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of a single Judge of the Kerala High Court dismissing the appellants suit for recovery of possession of certain property and for mesne profits.

facts.text: Only question of law is whether appeals could be heard by single Judge of High Court; other questions are purely questions of fact and not disputed

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the only question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the appeal companyld be heard and disposed of by a single Judge of the High Court. The other questions raised are purely questions of fact.

facts.text: Suit instituted on February 10, 1950 in district court of Kottayam

anchor.surface_text: As regards the question of law it is desirable to set out how, according to the appellant, it arises. The suit was instituted on February 10, 1950 in the district companyrt of Kottayam which was later transferred by it to the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Meenachil sometime in the year 1956

facts.text: Suit transferred to court of Subordinate Judge, Meenachil sometime in 1956

anchor.surface_text: in the district companyrt of Kottayam which was later transferred by it to the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Meenachil sometime in the year 1956 and was substantially decreed in the appellants favour on July 30, 1958.

facts.text: Suit substantially decreed in appellant's favour on July 30, 1958 by Subordinate Judge

anchor.surface_text: the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Meenachil sometime in the year 1956 and was substantially decreed in the appellants favour on July 30, 1958. Three appeals were preferred against it.

facts.text: Appeal by first defendant Tirumalaya Gounder against decree

anchor.surface_text: Three appeals were preferred against it. One was by Tirumalaya Gounder, the first defendant, and another in January, 1959 by H. B. Mohammad Rowther, 8th defendant.

facts.text: Appeal by 8th defendant H. B. Mohammad Rowther in January 1959

anchor.surface_text: One was by Tirumalaya Gounder, the first defendant, and another in January, 1959 by H. B. Mohammad Rowther, 8th defendant. The appellant had also preferred an appeal against that part of the decree which was adverse to him.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal against adverse part of decree

anchor.surface_text: H. B. Mohammad Rowther, 8th defendant. The appellant had also preferred an appeal against that part of the decree which was adverse to him. All these -appeals were heard together

facts.text: Three appeals heard together and disposed by common judgment on August 10, 1960 by Kerala High Court

anchor.surface_text: All these -appeals were heard together and disposed of by a ,common judgment on August 10, 1960 and the appeals preferred. by defendants I and 8 were allowed by the High Court while the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeals of defendants 1 and 8, dismissed appellant's appeal

anchor.surface_text: disposed of by a ,common judgment on August 10, 1960 and the appeals preferred. by defendants I and 8 were allowed by the High Court while the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed.

facts.text: Suit and appeals valued at Rs. 3,000

anchor.surface_text: The appellants suit and the appeals taken by the respondents from the District Court and the Subordinate Judge were both valued at Rs. 3,000 and, therefore, had ss. 20 and 21 of the Act been in force on the date on which the appeals were instituted unquestionably they would have had to be beard by a Division Bench of two Judges.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin High Court Act 5 of 1125 M.E. corresponding to 1949 A.D. was in force at time suit instituted

anchor.surface_text: At the time the suit was instituted the Travancore-Cochin High Court Act 5 of 1125 M.E.  Corresponding to 1949 A.D.  was in force. Under s. 20 of that Act read with S. 21 all appeals to the High Court valued at an amount in excess of Rs. 1,000 had to be heard by a Division Bench companysisting of two Judges of the High Court.

facts.text: Under Travancore-Cochin High Court Act ss.20 and 21, appeals over Rs.1000 to be heard by Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 20 of that Act read with S. 21 all appeals to the High Court valued at an amount in excess of Rs. 1,000 had to be heard by a Division Bench companysisting of two Judges of the High Court.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin High Court Act repealed by Kerala High Court Act 5 of 1959, assent February 6, 1959, force March 3, 1959

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid Act was, however, repealed by the Kerala High Court Act, 1958 being Act No. 5 of 1959 which received the assent of the President on February 6, 1959 and came into force on March 3, 1959.

facts.text: Under s.5 Kerala High Court Act 1959, single Judge jurisdiction extended to appeals not exceeding Rs.10,000

anchor.surface_text: The reason why the appeals were heard by a single Judge and number Placed before a Division Bench was that under s. 5 of the Kerala High Court Act 5 of 1959 the jurisdiction of a single Judge of the High Court to hear and dispose of appeals from an original- decree was extended to appeals in which the value of the subject matter did number exceed Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: Appeals placed for hearing before single Judge, overruling appellant's plea for Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: The appeals were placed for hearing before a single Judge overruling, we are informed by learned companynsel, the appellants plea that they should be only heard by a Division Bench.

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to interfere with High Court findings of fact as no grave errors shown

anchor.surface_text: it is the settled practice of this Court number to interfere with a finding of fact arrived at by the High Court unless it is satisfied that in arriving at the finding of fact the High Court had been guilty of -rave errors. We gave opportunity to learned companynsel to point out to us if the findings arrived at by the learned single Judge of the High Court are vitiated by any grave errors. But he was unable to point out any.

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to permit counsel to address on findings of fact

anchor.surface_text: But he was unable to point out any. We, therefore, declined to permit him to address us on the findings of fact.

facts.text: One contesting respondent raised question on maintainability of suit but Supreme Court declined to permit as not raised below

anchor.surface_text: One more point was sought to be urged by learned companynsel for the appellant. The point is based upon the fact that one of the companytesting respondents had raised a question as the maintainability of the suit. According to learned companynsel that person being in pari delicto with the plaintiff, ought number to have been permitted to raise that question. Since the point was number raised by the appellant in either of the two companyrts below we declined to permit it to be raised for the first time before us.

under Art. 136 to entertain an appeal from a decision of a single Judge, it is the settled practice of this Court not to interfere with a finding of fact arrived at by the High Court unless it is satisfied that in arriving at the finding of fact the High Court had been guilty of grave errors.

Article 133, cl. 3 of the Constitution clearly provides that notwithstanding anything in the article no appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from a judgment, decree or final order of one Judge of a High Court unless Parliament by law otherwise provides.

concepts.interpretation: No appeal lies to Supreme Court from single Judge of High Court unless Parliament provides otherwise; does not detract from Art. 136 power.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the only question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the appeal companyld be heard and disposed of by a single Judge of the High Court.

issues.text: whether by depriving the appellant of the right to have his appeal heard by a Division Bench his further right of appeal to this Court under Art. 133 was affected and that since that right also vested in him when he instituted the suit it could not be taken away retrospectively
whether that person being in pari delicto with the plaintiff, ought not to have been permitted to raise that question as the maintainability of the suit

anchor.surface_text: one of the contesting respondents had raised a question as the maintainability of the suit. According to learned counsel that person being in pari delicto with the plaintiff, ought number to have been permitted to raise that question.

arguments.claim: The right to have the appeals heard by a Division Bench conferred by the Travancore-Cochin High Court Act was not taken away expressly by Kerala Act 5 of 1959 and could not be taken away by implication

anchor.surface_text: According, to learned counsel the right to have the an-peals heard by a Division Bench conferred by the Travancore-Cochin High Court Act which was in force not only when the suit but also when the appeals were filed, was not taken away expressly by Kerala Act 5 of 1959 and could not be taken away by implication. In support of his contention he placed strong reliance upon the decision in Radhakrishan v. Shridhar

arguments.court_reasoning: Right to specific bench composition is procedural, not substantive vested right; Radhakrishan disapproved in Mahendra v Darsan

arguments.claim: The propositions in Garikapati Veeraya v N Subbiah Choudhury apply: right of appeal is vested substantive right from date of suit institution, governed by law then prevailing, taken away only expressly or by necessary intendment
arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with propositions but they concern substantive right to appeal under CPC s96, not procedural matter of bench strength

arguments.claim: Right to appeal derives from Travancore-Cochin High Court Act, not merely CPC s96
arguments.court_reasoning: High Court Act regulates procedure and business, preamble shows; substantive right from CPC s96

arguments.claim: No party has a vested right to have appeal heard by specified number of judges; bench composition is procedural matter
By depriving appellant of right to Division Bench hearing, vested right of appeal to Supreme Court under Art 133 is taken away retrospectively
arguments.court_reasoning: No vested right to Division Bench hearing, so no Art 133 right arises from single judge decision per Art 133 cl 3

arguments.claim: Contesting respondent in pari delicto with plaintiff ought not to have been permitted to raise question of suit maintainability

According to learned counsel that person being in pari delicto with the plaintiff, ought not to have been permitted to raise that question.

holdings.text: it is the settled practice of this Court not to interfere with a finding of fact arrived at by the High Court unless it is satisfied that in arriving at the finding of fact the High Court had been guilty of grave errors. We gave opportunity to learned counsel to point out to us if the findings arrived at by the learned single Judge of the High Court are vitiated by any grave errors. But he was unable to point out any. We, therefore, declined to permit him to address us on the findings of fact.

anchor.surface_text: it is the settled practice of this Court not to interfere with a finding of fact arrived at by the High Court unless it is satisfied that in arriving at the finding of fact the High Court had been guilty of -rave errors. We gave opportunity to learned counsel to point out to us if the findings arrived at by the learned single Judge of the High Court are vitiated by any grave errors. But he was unable to point out any. We, therefore, declined to permit him to address us on the findings of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel unable to show grave errors in High Court fact findings; settled practice limits review under Art. 136.

holdings.text: We are in respectful agreement with what has been laid down by this Court [in Garikapati]. But [...] this is not a case where any right of appeal conferred by law upon the appellant has been taken away. The right to prefer an appeal from the judgment of the court of first instance is derived from the provisions of s. 96 of the Code of Civil Procedure. [Travancore-Cochin High Court Act] merely dealt with procedural matters
holdings.reasoning_summary: Garikapati concerns substantive vested right to appeal under CPC s.96; High Court Act regulates procedure and business, not substantive rights.

holdings.text: No party has a vested right to have his appeal heard by a specified number of judges. An appeal lay to the High Court and the appeal in question was in fact heard and disposed by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: No party has a vested right to have his appeal heard by a specified number of judges. An appeal lay to the High Court and the appeal in question was in fact heard and disposed by the High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Composition of bench is procedural matter; applying Ittavira Mathai v. Varkey Varkey.

holdings.text: We, therefore, overrule the contention of the learned counsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges. In the circumstances, therefore, we must reject the appellants contention based upon the decision in Radhakishans case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Kerala High Court Act s.5 validly extended single judge jurisdiction retrospectively as procedural; Radhakrishan disapproved per Mahendra v. Darsan.

holdings.text: once it is held that no party has a vested right to have his appeal to be heard by more than one judge of the High Court, no right to prefer an appeal under Art. 133 can be said to vest in him, the right under which being unavailable in case heard And disposed of by a single judge of the High Court. The argument of learned counsel thus fails.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No vested right to division bench hearing means no corresponding Art.133 right vests, as Art.133 cl.3 bars appeal from single judge unless Parliament provides.

holdings.text: Since the point was not raised by the appellant in either of the two courts below we declined to permit it to be raised for the first time before us.
holdings.reasoning_summary: New arguments not permitted if not raised in lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his companytention he placed strong reliance upon the decision in Radhakrishan v. Shridhar 1 . In that case, just -,is here, the jurisdiction of a single Judge to hear an appeal of a value over Rs. 2,000 was challenged, even though by an amendment to an earlier rule made by the High Court in exercise of its power under el. 26 of the Letters Patent on May 27, 1948 all appeals from an appellate decree of a District Court were to be ordinarily heard and disposed of- by a single Judge. A companytention was raised on behalf of the appellants companynsel in that case that in the absence of any express provision rendering the amendment retrospective the amendment did number touch the right of an appellant which bad I.L.R. 1950 Nag. 532.

precedents.cited_proposition: In the absence of any express provision rendering the amendment retrospective the amendment did not touch the right of an appellant which had accrued to him earlier to have his appeal heard by a Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: This decision was number approved of in Mahendra v. Darsan 1  on the ground that the right of a party to have an appeal heard by a Division Bench was merely a matter of procedure and companyld, therefore, be taken away retrospectively by implication. ... The learned companynsel, however, companytended that in the instant case it is traceable to the provisions of Travancore- I.L.R. 31 Patna 446.

precedents.cited_proposition: the right of a party to have an appeal heard by a Division Bench was merely a matter of procedure and could, therefore, be taken away retrospectively by implication

precedents.citation: Garikapati Veerara v. N. Subbaiah Choudhury 2 ... 1957 S.C.R. 488

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant also placed reliance upon a decision of this Court in Garikapati Veerara v. N. Subbaiah Choudhury 2  in which the following propositions were laid down That the legal pursuit of a remedy, suit, appeal and second appeal are really but steps in a series of proceedings all companynected by an intrinsic unity and are to be regarded as one legal proceeding. The right of appeal is number a mere matter of procedure but is a substantive right. ... This vested right of appeal can be taken away only by a subsequent enactment, if it so provides expressly or by necessary intendment and number otherwise. ... 2  1957 S.C.R. 488

precedents.case_name: Garikapati Veerarao v. N. Subbaiah Choudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: The right of appeal is a vested substantive right governed by the law prevailing at the date of the institution of the suit and can be taken away only expressly or by necessary intendment
precedents.cited_holding: That the legal pursuit of a remedy, suit, appeal and second appeal are really but steps in a series of proceedings all connected by an intrinsic unity... This vested right of appeal can be taken away only by a subsequent enactment, if it so provides expressly or by necessary intendment and not otherwise.

precedents.citation: Ittavira Mathai v. Varkey Varkey another 1 ... 1964 1 S.C.R. 495

anchor.surface_text: An objection somewhat similar to the one raised by the appellant before us was raised before this Court in Ittavira Mathai v. Varkey Varkey another 1 . Dealing with it this Court has observed at p. 514 That reason is that an appeal lay to a High Court and whether it is to be heard by one, two or a larger number of judges is merely a matter of procedure. No party has a vested right to have his appeal heard by a specified number of judges. ... 1 1964 1 S.C.R. 495

precedents.cited_proposition: No party has a vested right to have his appeal heard by a specified number of judges; whether heard by one, two or more is merely procedural
precedents.cited_holding: No party has a vested right to have his appeal heard by a specified number of judges. An appeal lay to the High Court and the appeal in question was in fact heard and disposed by the High Court and, therefore, no right of the party has been infringed merely because it was heard by two judges and not by three judges.

precedents.cited_proposition: Right to Division Bench hearing cannot be taken away by implication

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, overrule the contention of the learned counsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's contentions on jurisdiction of single Judge and other points rejected; no interference with High Court findings of fact or judgment

edges.explanation: Issue on single judge hearing appeal directly engages Letters Patent cl.26 provisions on High Court appellate jurisdiction
Resolving whether appeal could be heard by single judge requires h3's holding on no vested right
i2 on effect of bench deprivation on Art. 133 requires h5's holding
p1 addresses procedural amendments to appeals without retrospective effect absent express provision, supporting the procedural nature of bench composition changes
p1 cited in context supporting the procedural characterization in h3

p2 states that the right of a party to have an appeal heard by a Division Bench was merely a matter of procedure, directly supporting the concept that bench composition is procedural with no vested right
p2's holding on procedural nature of Division Bench right supports h3's holding of no vested right to specified number of judges
a2 explicitly relies on and applies propositions from p3 Garikapati regarding vested right of appeal

edges.explanation: p3 Garikapati directly establishes the concept of vested right of appeal as a substantive right governed by the law prevailing at the time of suit institution

edges.explanation: p3 supports argument on vested right impact on Art 133 appeal
p4 explicitly states 'No party has a vested right to have his appeal heard by a specified number of judges', exactly matching the core of the concept
p4's statement matches verbatim the opening of h3 on no vested right to specified judges
p5 supports the vested right concept by stating right to Division Bench hearing cannot be taken away by implication
